sections: Two years ago, as Linda Bush‚Äôs mobility deteriorated and her husband began struggling with memory loss, the couple decided it was time to downsize from the single-family home in Meadville, Pennsylvania, where they‚Äôd lived for more than 46 years.
They moved into a new, nearby apartment building advertising to residents age 55 and over. ‚ÄúWe thought we‚Äôd have less stress,‚Äù says Bush, 71. ‚ÄúNow all I can do is laugh at that idea.‚Äù

Bush is now one of dozens of seniors in Meadville who could be forced out of their homes in the coming months, as their Wall Street-backed landlord hikes rents by as much as 39 percent. Their apartments

Seniors with Medicare coverage and access to pensions and home equity are a big business for Wall Street, but pumping vulnerable people for short-term returns has led to some disastrous results. As investors gobbled up nursing homes during the past two decades, a
found that resident death rates at private-equity owned facilities rose by 10 percent amidst devastating cuts made to maximize investor returns.

Now, faced with the rising labor costs and plummeting occupancy in long-term care facilities as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic ‚Äî as well as an aging population that‚Äôs remaining healthier for longer ‚Äî investors are
on senior living facilities where they can employ a tried-and-true strategy: jacking up rents on those who may have no place else to go. In addition to its
it is now ‚Äúthe largest owner of moderately priced age-restricted and age-targeted rental housing in the U.S.".
While the company‚Äôs CEO has touted these properties as a desirable alternative to publicly subsidized nursing homes, the aggressive rent hikes ‚Äî unusually steep even in a period of
‚Äî has left seniors like Bush with few options.

‚ÄúYes, we have Social Security and 401(k)s ‚Äî but we also [need] prescriptions, gas, and food,‚Äù said Bill Hohmann, 75, another resident in the Meadville senior building who has led efforts to push back on the increases.

Ironically, Americans‚Äô retirement savings are a major source of the capital that Welltower deploys to acquire and wring profits from senior housing and health care properties. As a publicly traded real-estate investment trust (REIT), the company‚Äôs shareholders include
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs robbing Peter to pay Paul,‚Äù said Tamar Katz, a former real-estate investment banker and co-author of a
from the Institute for New Economic Thinking on the role of REITs in financializing health care.

The paper questions the federal tax-exempt status of REITs, which control more than 500,000 properties in the U.S. ‚ÄúIs this the type of business that we, as an American public, want to be subsidizing with our tax code?‚Äù asks Katz. ‚ÄúTheir original purpose was to channel capital into productive investments ‚Äî not to price-gouge Grandma.‚Äù

While paying little in corporate taxes, Welltower has received more than $65 million in federal COVID-19 relief funds earmarked for health care providers, according to quarterly earnings reports, after spending at least $300,000 lobbying the federal government on issues including allocation of the funds.

‚ÄúCome as strangers, live as friends,‚Äù reads a brochure for Meadville‚Äôs Pine Street Commons, which also advertises amenities including an on-site library, community room, fitness center, and chapel.

The promise of community and convenience is part of what drew Hohmann to the newly built facility in the wake of his wife‚Äôs death in the fall of 2020, following more than 50 years of marriage. After selling their home in New York‚Äôs Hudson Valley, he relocated to Meadville, where his son and two grandchildren live, and prepared to start a new chapter.

When he arrived in May 2021, construction was still ongoing, with just 36 of the planned 128 units complete. The building still lacked both the advertised amenities and basic safety features like evacuation maps posted on the walls, he said. So that fall, Hohmann, who retired from a career in the U.S. Military Academy at West Point, organized residents to petition the building‚Äôs management, asking them to implement safety measures and provide a timeline for completing construction.

After the on-site management forwarded the petition on to the corporate office of Calamar, the New York-based developer and then-owner of the building, a company executive arrived to meet with residents.
‚ÄúHe gave us a six foot sub and took us out wine tasting ‚Äî all these things to make us feel warm and fuzzy,‚Äù Hohmann said. ‚ÄúI thought to myself, ‚ÄòWell, he‚Äôs not going to do anything.‚Äô‚Äù

Six months later, a different corporate executive returned to tell residents that though construction was still ongoing, they‚Äôd all be receiving substantial rent increases when their leases renewed over the course of the next year.
‚ÄúWhen I signed a lease, I asked what the annual increase would be,‚Äù Hohmann said. ‚ÄúThey told me 2 to 5 percent.‚Äù
Instead, Hohmann, Bush, and other residents who spoke to the
had all received rent hikes ranging from 20 to 39 percent, depending on their accommodations. Meadville is a small Rust Belt city with a median household income of $40,000,
U.S. Census data. Year-over-year rent increases in the two closest metro areas, Cleveland and Pittsburgh, were 8 percent and 6 percent respectively,
according to the most recent data

Bush and her husband live on approximately $3,800 a month. She draws Social Security as a retired part-time teacher, while he receives a modest pension from a career in the Social Security administration ‚Äî during most of which he was ineligible for the benefit himself. Their current monthly rent of $1,377 already accounts for more than a third of their monthly income, the benchmark for what‚Äôs considered affordable.
In March, rent on the couples‚Äô two-bedroom apartment is set to increase by more than $300, at which point it will eat up nearly half of their monthly budget.

Hohmann, Bush, and other residents have been asking Calamar to negotiate with them over the increases, recruiting support from local elected officials, and even staging ‚ÄúSupport Our Seniors‚Äù rallies locally and
At a July 2022 meeting with residents, covered by the
a Calamar executive refused to budge, saying that the company‚Äôs costs had risen with inflation ‚Äî by 9 percent.
‚ÄúTo operate, we need to cover those expenses. Unfortunately we‚Äôre passing them on to you,‚Äù the Calamar executive said,
. ‚ÄúWe have to show that revenue ‚Äî we have no option.‚Äù
Soon after that meeting, the Meadville residents received notice that their building ‚Äî along with 24 others throughout the Midwest owned by Calamar ‚Äî
by Welltower. Calamar remains the manager of the properties for now.
Neither Welltower nor Calamar responded to a request for comment.

Welltower acquired Bush and Hohmann‚Äôs Meadville building as part of the company‚Äôs growing focus on so-called ‚Äúwellness housing,‚Äù apartments for healthy seniors who don‚Äôt require intensive medical care or onsite assistance.

Speaking at a New York investor forum in 2020, then-Welltower CEO Tom DeRosa described wellness housing as a middle ground between luxury retirement homes and long-term care facilities for low-income seniors.
After working all their lives, ‚Äúmany people dispose of their assets and wave the white flag of destitution and go live their days in a Medicaid nursing home,‚Äù
The company expects ‚Äúsignificant future growth‚Äù in its wellness housing platform, Welltower wrote in a
last June. The firm claimed that such housing ‚Äúoperates with low-to-no staffing‚Äù ‚Äî in contrast to nursing homes, where labor is a major cost.

And unlike traditional multi-family apartments, where rent hikes are hemmed in by tenants‚Äô lagging paychecks, ‚Äúseniors housing is NOT INCOME DEPENDENT,‚Äù Welltower wrote, because many residents move in after selling off their homes and other assets. Shorter leases in senior housing also create the opportunity for more frequent rent increases, according to the business update.

While Hohmann sold his house in New York for a decent price, he has already decided that he‚Äôll move out of the Meadville building rather than stomach the rent increases. ‚ÄúI don't need to be flushing my grandchildrens‚Äô money away,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI think this is highway robbery.‚Äù

Bush and her husband are still unsure whether they‚Äôll stay or go ‚Äî another move would be difficult for both of them. To pay for their rent increase, they‚Äôre considering dipping into the mutual fund into which they put the proceeds from the sale of their house, even though Bush had been planning to rely on it in the event that she outlives her husband.
‚ÄúWe were counting on that,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúSo now we‚Äôll just have to live with that added stress.‚Äù
